Chapter 1 Introduction: History before the story begins

Around 3000 BC, when the glory of human civilization was only shining in a few limited areas of the Eurasian continent, the seeds of civilization and progress were also blooming on an island called Crete in the Mediterranean. The Minoan Dynasty was established on the island. In the following 500 years, clan-based city-states emerged and gradually influenced the surrounding areas. Around 1600 BC, which is equivalent to the time when the Shang Dynasty was established in China, the Minoan Dynasty in Crete flourished and its influence spread throughout the Aegean Sea.

In the eyes of the ancient Greeks, Crete was the place where Zeus, the "Lord of All Gods", lived before he entered Mount Olympus. He deceived Princess Io of Europa and gave birth to the first family members of the ruler of Crete on the island of Crete. The myth of the Greek hero Theseus killing the half-man, half-bull monster in the labyrinth took place on this island.

At the same time as the development of Cretan civilization, nomadic tribes from the Danube River basin migrated to the Peloponnese Plain and surrounding mountains in the Balkan Peninsula. They claimed to be descendants of the god Heron, so they were collectively called "Greeks". Around 1450 BC, the Mycenae they founded defeated the Knossos Palace on Crete Island. The Mycenaean civilization replaced the Cretan civilization and became the new overlord of the Aegean Sea.

Around 1193 BC, Agamemnon, King of Mycenae, joined forces with the kings of other Greek city-states to declare war on Troy, the overlord of Asia Minor. This is the Trojan War known to the world. The blind poet Homer compiled a myth about it, attributing the spark of the first Eurasian war of interests recorded in the epic to a super beauty named Helen.

The war lasted for ten years, Troy fell and Mycenae won, but the long war consumed the strength of the Mycenaean city-states, and they were soon gradually conquered by the Dorians who later entered the Balkan Peninsula, and a 400-year dark age entered Greek history.

During this period, the Dorians established a number of city-states, the most famous of which was Sparta.

After the Dark Ages, Greece entered the Archaic Age, where the economy and culture developed greatly. Due to the reforms of the Athenian politician Solon and the Spartan politician Lycurgus in their respective city-states, Athens and Sparta quickly became the two pearls of the Balkan Peninsula, and also the typical representatives of democracy and oligarchy in Greek city-states.

But the most powerful Greek city-state at that time was not these two, but Lydia from Asia Minor, which was said to be founded by the descendants of Hercules. It was called the "Golden Kingdom" for its abundant gold, but it attracted the covetousness of the great Middle Eastern empire Persia. It quickly destroyed Lydia and continued to attack westward, and the Greek city-states in Asia Minor surrendered. Then, the Persian Empire cast its greedy eyes on the Greek mainland. The proud Athens and Spartans refused Persia's persuasion to surrender, so the First Greco-Persian War broke out, and the Athenians defeated the Persian army in the Battle of Marathon.

But this was just a tentative military action by Persia, and the failure did not have much impact on the Persian Empire. Ten years later, the Persian Empire launched another attack on Greece, mobilizing more than 1,200 warships and more than 200,000 combat troops, an unprecedentedly large scale, in an attempt to destroy Greece in one fell swoop. Unexpectedly, at Thermopylae, the Spartan coalition of only 7,000 people hit the Persian king head-on, and the Persians left more than 20,000 bodies here. Finally, with the help of Greek traitors, they used a small path to go around the back of Thermopylae, and attacked from both sides, and finally opened up the road to the south.

Then in the Battle of Salamis, the clever and brave Athenian navy defeated the stronger Persian navy and buried the entire Persian fleet. From then on, the Persian navy was unable to recover and handed over control of the Aegean Sea.

Finally, a decisive battle was fought between 100,000 Persian troops and 60,000 Greek troops at Plataea. Due to an accidental event (the death of the Persian commander), Greece reversed the entire situation and won the Second Persian War.

Then, the Greeks began to fight back, cleared the Persian occupation forces in the Greek peninsula, and controlled various strategic locations from the Aegean Sea to the Black Sea. Among them, Athens' powerful navy dominated the entire war, while the conservative Spartans retreated to their homeland and rarely participated in external affairs, which made Athens the de facto leader of Greece. In addition, Athens had an excellent politician, Pericles, who was elected as the chief general of Athens for many years. He was not only good at reconciling the conflicts among various forces in the city, but also formulated a series of effective development plans. Under his leadership, Athens developed rapidly in various aspects such as economy, culture, and military. As Pericles boasted, "Athens has become the school of all Greece."

The prosperity of Athens naturally threatened the position of the old overlord Sparta. At that time, there were two alliances in Greece. One was the Delian League, which was led by Athens. Its influence spread throughout the coastal city-states and islands of the Aegean Sea and was mainly based on the navy. The other was the Peloponnesian League, which was led by Sparta and mainly consisted of city-states in the Peloponnese Peninsula and the central region of Greece. Its army was characterized by spearmen.

The opposition between the Land Alliance and the Sea Alliance became increasingly apparent, and conflict was inevitable. Finally, in 460 BC, one city-state withdrew from the Peloponnesian League and joined Athens, triggering the First Peloponnesian War. The war lasted until 446 BC, when the two sides ended in a tie and signed a peace treaty. By 430 BC, the war broke out again. On land, the Spartans attacked, and Athens relied on the walls built before the war to defend. At sea, the Athenians used their navy to harass the Spartans' rear, and the two sides fought each other, and the war continued.

In the second year of the war, a plague broke out in Athens, killing about a quarter of the people, including Pericles. This was a huge blow to the Athenians.

After the war lasted for ten years, the two sides signed a peace treaty again. Soon after the peace treaty was signed, the two sides fought again because of Argos (a city-state on the Peloponnese Peninsula that sided with Athens because of its opposition to Sparta), and the Athenians were defeated.

In 418 BC, the twelfth year of the war, the young Athenian general Alcibiades launched a dangerous plan against the Athenians: an expedition to Sicily.

The city-states of Sicily, mainly Syracuse, were the overseas grain and grass bases of Sparta and even the entire Peloponnese. Occupying Sicily was equivalent to cutting off the rear grain supply of the Spartan allies. Moreover, although the peace treaty was signed at that time, the Spartan coalition was unwilling to return the occupied land outside Athens, and the food supply of the Athenians was relatively tight. Conquering Sicily was a matter of killing two birds with one stone, and the Citizens' Assembly passed this resolution.

So, a force of 27,000 people, including 134 triremes, 130 transport ships, 5,100 heavy infantry, 1,300 archers, and 30 horses, led by generals Nicias, Alcibiades, and Lamachus, marched towards Sicily.

After landing, Lamachus proposed to attack Syracuse directly, but was opposed by Alcibiades, who advocated political means to encourage other Sicilian countries to oppose Syracuse. He got the support of Nicias, but no Sicilian city-state responded to the Athenian call, and all attempts failed completely.

At this time, a ship came from Athens, saying that Alcibiades was involved in the destruction of statues in Athens and ordered him to return to the country for trial.

Alcibiades pretended to agree, and on his way back home, he took the opportunity to escape.

Syracuse heard about the Athenian expeditionary force's intention and decided to take the initiative to attack, but was defeated. The Athenians took the opportunity to sail their fleet into the harbor, set up camp, and began to build a long siege wall and ring wall outside Syracuse. The Syracusans sent people out of the city many times to obstruct the construction of the wall, and frequent battles broke out, all of which ended in failure. However, in one battle, Lamachus was killed.

The situation in Syracuse was very critical, and they asked for help from their mother city Corinth. The Peloponnesian League quickly sent reinforcements. A force of about 2,000 heavy infantry and light infantry led by Spartan senior commander Gylippus quickly landed near Syracuse and began to raid the rear of the Athenians, forcing the Athenians to stop building the long wall that was almost completed.

Niceas was extremely frustrated and sent a report to Athens. The main point of the report was that the expeditionary force was in a difficult situation and had to either retreat or reinforce.

Athens was unwilling to give up the siege, believing that it would damage their national prestige, so it decided to send a second expedition.

Gylippus decided to launch a counterattack and capture the enemy's naval base at Primyrium. He first had the Syracusan fleet provoke a battle at sea to draw the Athenian forces, and then had the army attack the empty Primyrium.

The result went as he planned, and the Athenian fleet won the victory but lost their naval base.

The Sicilian coalition now controlled the entrance and exit to the Grand Harbor, and the Athenians were forced to return to their old base in the Grand Harbor.

When he heard that Athens' reinforcements would arrive soon, Gylippus decided to launch another counterattack. This time the plan was to attack both land and sea at the same time, but the land attack was a feint.

As a result, he succeeded again. Although he only sank seven Athenian ships, he completely destroyed the morale of the Athenian fleet and enabled the Syracuse to gain the initiative at sea.

Life became harder for the Athenians, and this is when our story begins...

Its northeast corner is close to the Apennine Peninsula, its southwest corner overlooks Carthage, and its southeast corner is located at the boundary between deep and shallow seas. Countless seabirds circled and soared in the clear sky, and their loud cries seemed to echo the ancient tune of the Mediterranean.

From this position, he could only vaguely see the Athenian camp, but in his mind he imagined the Athenian sailors repairing the warships with their heads down. He even thought of buying a few Athenian prisoners after the war was won and beating them up every day to relieve his hatred.

Suddenly, several loud bird calls caught his attention. The seabirds that were foraging to the north of the lighthouse flew high in the sky in panic. A sail appeared on the calm sea. Dozens of triremes soon came into Rathmans' sight.

"Athenian reinforcements!" Latomans' heart suddenly tightened.

Most of the heavy infantry were wealthy citizens who owned land in the city-state, while the sailors were poor people without land, and the status of the two was very different. However, the situation in Athens was different, because Athens' prosperity came from the strength of the Athenian navy, and the status of Athenian sailors was greatly improved. This disparity in economic status and the difference in political and military importance made the two armies always have some minor frictions when they were together.

But he didn't expect that Shiloh, who was only 18 years old, would rush to join the expedition without two years of reserve service. "Everyone, take your positions!" Nurnusis looked ahead and shouted solemnly, "Lower the sails!"

"Lower the sails!!"

"Paddle!"

"Paddle up!!"

More than a hundred ships formed a huge arrow shape, with three rows of oared warships on the outside, surrounding the transport ships in the center.

Thousands of oars were paddling rapidly on the sea at the same time, stirring up waves. The sounds of horns and splashing water came one after another, which was truly spectacular.

The soldiers stood on both sides of the ship, and they could even see the Syracuse soldiers on the coast beating their shields and cursing loudly. At this time, it was useless for them to be anxious, and everything depended on the performance of the Athenian navy.

"I begin to sing about bright-eyed Pallas Athena, defender of the city..." Someone began to hum the hymn to Athena, and gradually the singing spread to the entire fleet.

"She is fear, and like Ares she loves war,

The plundered city was filled with the cries of war.

Those who went out to fight were saved by her and returned.

Oh! Goddess, you give us blessings and joy! "

The passionate and powerful voice hovered over the rough sea, as if the Syracuse people were intimidated and did not send a fleet to block the attack.

The Athenian fleet sailed into the harbor in a mighty manner.

Late at night, Liu Xing was awakened by the urge to urinate. He went to the toilet in a daze and was about to return to his bedroom. The light coming from the next room made him stop.

"Xiaoxing, your dad and I are going out for a few days to do some big business. Your brother is in poor health and has gotten worse recently. He loves playing computer games and sits there all day. You must help mom look after him at home and make sure he goes to bed on time!" Liu Xing remembered his mother's repeated warnings before she left, and he walked to the door hesitantly.

Liu Xing has always been afraid of his brother. At first, it was because of his brother Liu Hai's appearance. Liu Hai was born with transposition of the great arteries (a complex congenital heart disease). Although he had a timely operation to save his life, he was skinny since childhood, his whole body was bruised (due to congestion caused by poor heart pumping function). Due to poor development, he looked strange, and in dim light, he looked like a ghost. So Liu Xing never dared to face his brother. Even when talking, he looked around and didn't look at his face.

Later, his parents' farm grew bigger and bigger, and they hired a lot of people. Liu Hai volunteered to help manage it. After half a year, the farm was in good order and the efficiency doubled. The staff was in awe of the boy in the wheelchair, not because of his appearance, but because he was clear about rewards and punishments and strict management. Liu Xing had seen him scolding people, and his tone was so harsh and his words were so harsh that even Liu Xing was terrified when he heard it from the side.

So when Liu Xing stood in front of the door and knocked carefully, he was mentally prepared to be scolded, but there was no response from inside the house.

"Brother! It's too late, time to go to bed!" Liu Xing shouted bravely.

There was still no response from the room.

Liu Xing hesitantly pushed open the half-open door: Liu Hai was lying motionless on the desk, and the computer screen in front of him was covered with bright red.

Liu Xing's heart immediately tightened and he hurried over.

"Brother! Brother! Don't scare me! Speak! Speak quickly!..." Liu Xing was still a child after all. He was totally confused at the moment and pushed Liu Hai's stiff body in a daze.

The wheelchair that Liu Hai was sitting on slid backwards, and he fell forward. He just turned over and revealed his lifeless, gray-black face. That scary face was unusually peaceful at this moment.

After nineteen years of suffering from illness, he finally found relief.

The tents propped up with linen could not completely block the cool breeze blowing from the sea, and the wailing of the wounded soldiers was even more miserable than during the day.

In this era of extremely backward technology, medical skills were still at the stage of religion and witchcraft medicine. When people got seriously ill, they would go to the temple to seek medical treatment or ask the witch to make spells for treatment. When ordinary doctors faced serious illnesses, apart from prescribing some peaceful and harmless herbs, the only method was bloodletting.

On the battlefield, when soldiers were injured or sick, they could only rely on their own physical strength to resist the disease. Everything was left to fate, and there was no other way. However, Hero was shot through the chest by an arrow, which was a serious injury that could not be more serious. In the past, such patients would not last long, but he was in a coma for only two days and recovered. This made all the doctors and wounded soldiers firmly believe that he was favored by Asclepius. So this afternoon, they all surrounded him, asking him what he dreamed about in his coma, and even touched the scar on his chest with their hands, hoping to get a little "divine spirit".

After being harassed by the wounded soldiers for a long time, Hilo, who had just woken up, still couldn't fall asleep in the dark night. Because he was Liu Hai, a Chinese with Hilo's memory. After an afternoon of indirect questioning, he was sure that he was neither dreaming nor seeing hell, but came to a strange world. Although he didn't know what brought him here, he knew that he could never go back to this parallel world after reading several books written by Mr. Hawking.

His parents, who had always loved him deeply and had been worried about his illness, and his younger brother, whom he had always wanted to get close to and love, he will never see again in this life!

While he was depressed, he was also grateful. He had been suffering from illness for many years and knew very well that when he was reading the History of the Peloponnesian War and preparing to answer a question from a netizen, he suddenly suffered from left heart failure and the accompanying lung failure, which had brought his life to an end... Now he has regained his life, and it is a young and energetic life. Although he is no longer a Chinese, this is enough to make him grateful. Only those who always worry that their lives will be blown out like a candle will deeply feel the preciousness of life.

This time, the God whom he had always cursed compensated him.

But the thief God was simply torturing him. He had just escaped the embrace of the god of death, and now he was facing death again. By analyzing the words of the wounded in the afternoon, he could determine that he had come to the ancient Mediterranean era of Athens and Sparta. The turning point of the Peloponnesian War was the Sicily expedition, where an Athenian army of about 50,000 people attacked Syracuse and was eventually defeated and annihilated. And now he was a member of this expeditionary force.

"Am I going to die again just after I came back to life?" He clenched his fists unwillingly. The thick muscles bulging in his arms seemed to encourage him: "No! I have to find a way to escape! I must escape!"

But how to escape? In Hero's remaining memory, he was just an Athenian citizen who had just turned 18. Although his family was rich, he was too young to give a speech at the Citizens' Assembly, and he had never held any public office. In this army, he was just an ordinary heavy infantryman. In a word, he was a newcomer and had no influence. Even if he told the general every day, "Athens will fail, we should retreat!" No one would believe him. Instead, they would lock him up for disturbing the morale of the army.

In terms of being knowledgeable about the world, the eighteen-year-old Liu Hai is not comparable to the original eighteen-year-old Xi Luo: he has suffered from the contempt of the world since he was a child, and in order not to be isolated, he learned to read people's eyes and curry favor; later he dropped out of school due to poor health and helped his parents start a business. He got used to the administrative faces of village cadres and town leaders who could make things happen at will; later, when the company grew bigger, he helped his parents manage personnel, and he also enjoyed a lot of flattery, treats and gifts from those employees.

Since he had guessed this possibility, and was not absolutely sure, he would not be foolish enough to go directly to the general and expose himself completely.

He tried hard to recall the historical materials he had read about the Sicilian Expedition, but unfortunately he was not a professional historian and only knew the general process. Moreover, this era was too long ago and the information that could be passed down was very few.

Since the Athenian reinforcements have just arrived, there is probably still more than a month before the final destruction, and he doesn't have much time left!

Chapter 15 Cavalry Raid

The soldiers of early Athens came from the four major clan groups in the city. The battles were mainly with neighboring city-states, and both sides lined up in battle array. Fighting was customary, and the battles could often be ended in one day and the troops could return to the city. The whole process was simple, the army was crudely organized, and there was no logistics system.

After the reform of Cleisthenes, the Athens area was divided into dozens of demos (equivalent to villages), and the order of all the demos was disrupted, each belonging to thirty regions. During the slack season, each demo organized military training, and soldiers were drawn before war and commanded by generals or senior commanders. The battles were still simple and there was no strict military system.

Until the conflict with Sparta, each war lasted no longer just one day, but one month, two months, or even more than a year (such as the Sicily Expedition). Athens' old military system could no longer meet the needs of war and had to be reformed, and the model to learn from was its enemy, Sparta.

The biggest difference between the Spartan army and all the Greek city-states is that its soldiers are all professional soldiers. During the Greco-Persian War, a Spartan general asked his allied soldiers from various city-states what their occupations were. Everyone answered enthusiastically, including bricklayers, potters, vendors... Only the Spartan soldiers said nothing. Seeing this, the Spartan general laughed and said that only we Spartans are real warriors.

The Spartans began to receive training from a young age, and did nothing else in their lives except training and fighting. Therefore, they were stronger than other city-states in terms of combat skills, tactics, and military organization.

The enemy is the best teacher. Although Athens could not have professional soldiers, it learned from Sparta in terms of military system in order to better organize soldiers to fight. They divided the army into smaller units, with the smallest combat unit being a squad, which consisted of 10 people, enough to form a small 8x8 square, and the captain was a soldier with rich combat experience.

Chapter 31 History of the Shiloh Family:
Chapter 31 History of the Shiloh Family

There are four life-size blue steel statues in Shiloh's bedroom.

The first one from the left is a strong man holding a hammer. According to his memory, Hilo knew that it was his "great-great-grandfather", who came from the mountains of Macedonia and was once a slave of a Lydian nobleman, responsible for the manufacture of weapons. Once the master went out of the city and met a lioness on the road, everyone fled in all directions, only his great-great-grandfather stood up and fought with the lion with the strength he had gained from years of blacksmithing. He finally drove away the lioness, saved the master, and was granted freedom. Later, due to the war between Lydia and Persia and the turbulent times, he came to Athens by boat and settled in the port of Piraeus. He made a living by making shields and spears for others. Gradually, he became famous and then had his own weapons workshop. In the Greco-Persian War, he became an Athenian foreign soldier and died in the Battle of Plataea.

The second statue is a simple-looking man who is looking at the account book in his hand seriously. Hero knew that this was his great-grandfather. After his great-great-grandfather died, as the only son, his great-grandfather took over the family business, worked hard to expand the customer base, and finally became a famous weapons manufacturer in Athens. With sufficient funds, he began to get involved in other industries: pottery making, textiles and simple currency exchange. Just when the family business was thriving, bad news came: his two sons followed General Cimon to recover the Greek city-states occupied by the Persians in Asia Minor, and died in battle with the Persian navy. The great-grandfather fell ill and his business suddenly stagnated and began to lose money. At this time, his youngest son rushed back from Egypt.

The third statue is Hero's grandfather, pointing his finger into the distance with a high spirit. In his grandfather's generation, due to the relatively affluent life, the grandfather, as the youngest son, loved to play since childhood. When he grew up, he liked adventure travel. He went to many places, made many friends, and became knowledgeable. When he rushed back home, the family business had declined rapidly. He raised the remaining funds against all odds, bought a ship, and started maritime trade. A few years later, he opened up a grain trade shipping channel with the Black Sea, and from then on, he made a fortune. After the first conflict between Athens and Sparta, he led a fleet to deliver grain to the Athenian army on the expedition when he was over fifty years old. He encountered a storm on the way and sank with the ship.

The fourth statue is Hero's father, Hepias, who makes powerful gestures and seems to be giving a speech to others. Although Hepias' father is rich, he has one biggest regret, which is that he cannot become an Athenian citizen. Hepias received the best education in Athens since he was a child. When he grew up, in order to realize his father's last wish, he made friends with Athenian nobles, went to various social occasions, donated money to the council many times, and often paid out of his own pocket to let Athenian citizens watch dramas for free. Finally, the proposal was passed unanimously: when Hepias' son came of age, he would be granted Athenian citizenship, and until then he would be under the guardianship of Pericles.
